column1: Massillon is a city in Stark County in the U.S. state of Ohio
column2: approximately 8 miles (13 km) west of Canton
column4: and 50 miles (80 km) south of Cleveland. The population was 32
column5: 149 at the 2010 census
column6: which makes it the 44th largest city in Ohio.

column1: Massillon is the second largest incorporated area within the Canton-Massillon
column2: OH Metropolitan Statistical Area.  As of the 2010 census
column3: the metropolitan area had a population of 404
column4: 422 and includes all of Stark and Carroll counties.

column1: The city's incorporated area primarily resides in the western half of Perry Township
column2: with portions extending north into Jackson Township
column4: and south into Bethlehem Township. The village of Navarre borders the city to the south.

column1: The original settlement of Kendal was founded in 1812 by Thomas Rotch
column2: a Quaker originally of New Bedford
column4: and Hartford
column5: Connecticut. James Duncan of New Hampshire first settled in Kendal before recording the plot for Massillon on December 6
column6: 1826. Duncan
column8: named the town after Jean Baptiste Massillon
column10: at the request of his wife.  The town plat was established along the east bank of the Tuscarawas River
column11: which was the surveyed route for the Ohio and Erie Canal being constructed to connect Lake Erie with the Ohio River. The canal section spanning from Cleveland to Massillon was completed in 1828. Massillon quickly became a major port town along the canal route
column12: known as the Port of Massillon
column13: following the canal's completion in the 1832. The first telegraph lines would reach Massillon in 1847
column14: and the Ohio & Pennsylvania Railroad would extend its rails to Massillon in 1852. Massillon incorporated as a village in 1853. In 1868
column15: Massillon incorporated as a city when the populated reached 5

column2: formed in 1842 by Charles. M. Russell and his brothers
column4: manufactured threshing machines and other agricultural implements in Massillon. The company began producing train cars in 1852 and incorporated in 1864 as Russell & Company Inc. In 1884
column5: Russell & Company began producing its famed steam traction engines and quickly became one of the largest producers of industrial and agricultural equipment.  A merger with the Griscom-Spencer company in 1912 created the Griscom-Russell Company. Griscom-Russell produced heat exchangers for the United States Navy during World War II.  The company closed in 1962.

column1: The Massillon Iron Bridge Company was founded by Joseph Davenport in 1869  after moving to Massillon from Boston to work at the C. M. Russell & Company. Davenport also invented and built the first locomotive "cowcatcher" and cab in Massillon. The company incorporated in 1887 as The Massillon Bridge Company. The Massillon Bridge Company designed and built steel truss bridges up through the mid-1900s
column2: many of which stand today.

column1: The Massillon State Hospital for the Insane opened in 1898  on 240 acres of land given to the state of Ohio for the purpose of constructing the hospital. The hospital was established by Ohio governor William McKinley. By 1950 there were 3
column2: 100 patients in the hospital.  Today it is known as Heartland Behavioral Healthcare.

column1: The Forest City Motor Company was founded in Cleveland in 1906 but relocated to Massillon that same year. Forest City produced approximately 1
column2: 000 of their Jewel automobiles in Massillon between 1906 and 1909. The name of the company was changed to the Jewel Motor Car Company but the company eventually ceased production in 1909.

column1: Although steelmaking and fabrication is found throughout its history
column2: some say Massillon's steel age didn't start until 1909
column3: when the first sheet of steel was rolled at the Massillon Rolling Mill Company. Massillon Rolling merged into the Central Steel Company in 1914
column4: and lit its first open hearth furnace in 1915. Central Steel eventually became known as the Central Alloy Steel Company. In April 1930
column5: Central Alloy merged with Republic Steel
column6: becoming the third largest steel company in the world
column7: with its Massillon operations employing nearly one-half of the city's workforce by 1959.  This included other Massillon divisions like Massillon Union Drawn Steel and its stainless steel division Enduro Stainless.  In 1984 Republic Steel was purchased by LTV Steel.  Enduro closed in 1985
column8: and it and other stainless plants went through several ownership changes over the following 15 years.  The main Republic facilities on the southwest side of Massillon closed by 2002.

column1: Stanley Macomber designed the open-web steel joist in 1921 while working for Massillon's Central Steel Company. Macomber left Central Steel and founded the Massillon Steel Joist Co. in 1923. His open-web steel joist
column2: patented in 1924
column3: was known as the Massillon Steel Joist. Macomber's invention was a revolutionary assembly of steel joists with a top slab used to support of floors
column4: ceilings and roofs. The basis of Macomber's steel joist design is still used today. Stanley Macomber was inducted into the Inventors Hall of Fame in 2011.

column2: the first U.S. highway to run from coast to coast
column3: was envisioned in 1913  and followed Main Street through the center of Massillon.  Main Street was eventually renamed Lincoln Way in recognition of the new highway. In 1928
column4: the federal government renamed Lincoln Highway to U.S. 30. A controlled access freeway was constructed in 1971
column5: bypassing U.S. 30 around to the city's most southern part. The old Lincoln Highway that runs through Massillon and Canton was reassigned as State Route 172.

column1: Massillon was a site where one of the most tragic instances of anti-union violence in the history of the United States occurred. The Steel Workers Organizing Committee began an attempt to organize workers at Republic Steel in the spring of 1937
column2: following the unionizing of workers at the country's two largest steel companies US Steel and Jones & Laughlin Steel. In retaliation
column3: Republic Steel expelled over 1000 union supporters at plants in Canton and Massillon. On May 26
column4: the union eventually called for all workers at Republic Steel
column5: Youngstown Sheet and Tube
column6: and Inland Steel (together known as Little Steel) to strike in response to the treatment of workers in Massillon and Canton.

column3: a car failed to dim its headlights as it approached a police barricade near a picket line at one of the Massillon plants. City police assumed the worst and without warning opened fire with rifles and shotguns. Police then used this infraction to raid a peaceful crowd that was gathered in front of the union headquarters. Police pumped tear gas canisters and opened fire into the fleeing crowd. Joined by National Guardsmen
column4: the police destroyed the union hall and arrested every suspected unionist they could find. Three men were killed and hundreds were injured during this incident.Ohio Historical Marker #18-76 was erected in 2004 in front of the Massillon City Hall in memory of the Little Steel Strike of 1937.

column2: Sr.
column3: sometimes known as General Coxey of Massillon
column4: was an American politician who ran for elective office several times in Ohio. He twice led Coxey's Army
column6: consisting of a group of unemployed men that he led on marches from Massillon to Washington
column8: to present a "Petition in Boots" demanding that the Congress allocate funds to create jobs for the unemployed. Although his march failed
column9: Coxey's Army was an early attempt to arouse political interest in an issue that grew in importance until the Social Security Act of 1935 encouraged the establishment of state unemployment insurance programs.

column1: Jacob Coxey was elected mayor of Massillon in 1931 and served one year.

column1: The Massillon Museum was established in 1933 in order to preserve the city's rich history. The museum was accredited in 1972 by the American Alliance of Museums and is currently located downtown in the historic Gensemer Brothers Dry Goods building. The museum's collection encompasses approximately 100
column2: 000 objects  in 94 categories
column4: 000 photographs
column5: and 18
column6: 000 archival and reference documents. The Immel Circus is one of the museum's most interesting collections. The 100-square foot miniature circus contains 2
column13: 207 people. Most of the pieces were hand-carved by Dr. Robert Immel of Massillon using tools from his dental practice.

One of the theatre's two arc-lamp 35mm projectors was replaced by a digital projector in 2013. Today the theatre hosts community events
column4: and screens classic and second-run movies on weekends. The stage also hosts live theatre. In 1989

column1: Spring Hill Historic Home is the home of Thomas and Charity Rotch
column2: the founders of Kendal
column4: the home of the Rotch-Wales families was turned into a historic home and opened to the public. Today
column5: they focus on the Underground Railroad work that Thomas and Charity did while living in the house. The house is a member of the Ohio Friends of Freedom Society
column6: and became a site on the National Park Service's Network to Freedom in 2006. Perhaps one of the most exciting parts of their Underground Railroad history is a letter written by George Duncan
column7: a freedom seeker who was still on the run
column8: to Thomas and Charity. George trusted the Rotches to help reunite him with his companion Edy
column9: who was waiting for safer passage before escaping herself. George's letter is one of only a few written by a formerly enslaved person while they were still on the run.

column1: The Ohio Military Museum is operated by the Ohio Society Of Military History and is home to thousands of artifacts and tributes to the men and women of Ohio who served in the armed forces. The museum moved to the MAPS Air Museum in 2016.
The City of Massillon Parks & Recreation Department operates a recreation center
column2: senior center
column3: and 35 parks and open spaces. Massillon's municipal golf course
column4: The Legends of Massillon
column5: opened in 1995. The City maintains the Stark County section of the Sippo Valley Bike & Hike Trail
column6: leading trail users to Dalton in Wayne County.  The Ohio and Erie Canal Towpath Trail also passes through the city.

column1: Football has long been one of the most prominent contributions to the culture of Massillon.
While the first players known to be paid to play football are believed to have played for club teams in the Pittsburgh
column2: Pennsylvania area
column3: perhaps the first great professional football rivalry was between the Massillon Tigers and Canton Bulldogs from 1903 to 1906 and 1915 to 1919. This rivalry predates both the NFL and the aforementioned rivalry between the Massillon and Canton high schools which continue to use the nicknames of these early professional teams. The Professional Football Researchers Association (PFRA) web site includes articles about the early years of this rivalry
column4: as well as articles about the history of football through the 1970s.

column1: The name Massillon is most notably associated with the Massillon Washington High School football team
column2: the Tigers. Distinguished Massillon alumni include former Ohio State University
column4: and Cincinnati Bengals coach Paul Brown
column5: and former Ohio State University player and former NFL All-Pro linebacker Chris Spielman. The Tigers are historically one of the winningest high school football teams in the United States
column6: second only to Valdosta High School in Valdosta
column7: Georgia. Along with the Canton McKinley High School Bulldogs
column8: the Tigers represent one half of what many consider to be the greatest high school football rivalry in the nation.  Both Massillon and their fierce rivalry with Canton are subjects of the 2001 documentary film Go Tigers!.

column1: The construction of Paul Brown Tiger Stadium in Massillon was completed in 1939 through the Works Progress Administration program. The stadium currently holds 16
column2: 884 people and is named after former Tiger player and head coach Paul Brown. Besides being the regular season home of the Massillon Tiger Football team
column3: the stadium hosts numerous Ohio High School Athletic Association state football playoff games as well as divisional championship games. The stadium also hosts the annual Pro Football Hall of Fame drum and bugle corps competition. The stadium is marked with a historical marker dedicated to Paul Brown and his contribution to the sport

column1: === Paul L. David Athletic Training Center ===
Massillon's Paul L. David Athletic Training Center was built in 2008 by local philanthropist Jeff David in honor of his late father. The 3 million dollar
column3: 000 square foot building is the largest indoor football practice facility in the state of Ohio
column5: 000-square-feet larger than the facility used by the NFL's Cleveland Browns.

column1: The Massillon Tigers have accumulated 24 state AP championships and 9 national AP championships during the school's history. As of 2012
column2: the Tigers have accumulated an overall record of 837-249-35
column3: a record not approached by any other Ohio high school football team. In the years since the Ohio high school playoff system was instituted in 1972
column4: the Tigers have accumulated a current record of 316-117-4. The Tigers have made the playoffs 19 times
column5: the final four six times
column6: and the final championship game three times. There have been 23 professional players
column8: and 14 collegiate all-Americans that have graduated from Massillon Washington High School.

column1: Washington High School currently holds the record for the most playoff appearances by a high school football team without actually winning a state championship since 1970.

The Massillon Tiger Swing Band was created by George "Red" Bird in 1938 during the Paul Brown era of Massillon football. The band became known as "The Greatest Show in High School Football" and is still a very important part of the Massillon football tradition. The band's swing style includes moving formations and musicians marching with a swing step. Bird invented the 6 to 5 step. The Tiger Swing band begins every home football game with the traditional hometown songs of Massillon Will Shine
column2: Stand Up and Cheer (to acknowledge the other team)
column4: Eye of the Tiger and the WHS Alma Mater. At the beginning of each half time show
column5: they perform what is known as "Opening Routine." This is a tradition that goes back for decades and consists of the band's entrance ("Turn Arounds") followed by Fanfare
column6: Tiger Rag and Carry On. This entire routine is marched at 180 beats per minute and is practiced through the entire season from the beginning of the rehearsals in the summer time.

column1: In July 2008 Massillon was nominated as one of only twenty cities nationwide as a finalist in ESPN's "Titletown U.S.A." contest. On July 21
column2: a rally was held at Paul Brown Tiger Stadium while ESPN filmed a segment that was aired on SportsCenter. Massillon finished fourth in the voting behind Valdosta
column4: West Virginia; and Green Bay
